Pros
+ Timeless gameplay: TF2's core gameplay remains incredibly fun and engaging, even after all these years. The class-based system, with its diverse roles and playstyles, offers a high skill ceiling and endless replayability.
+ Thriving community: TF2 boasts a large and dedicated community that creates custom content, organizes events, and keeps the game alive.
+ Unique art style: TF2's distinctive art style has aged remarkably well and continues to be visually appealing.

Cons
- Bot crisis: A major ongoing issue is the prevalence of bots in casual matches. These bots disrupt gameplay, cheat, and often flood the chat with spam, making the experience frustrating for many players.
- Balancing issues: Some classes and weapons can feel overpowered or underpowered, leading to balance concerns. While updates try to address these issues, it's an ongoing process.
- Outdated engine: TF2's aging engine can cause performance issues for some players, especially on lower-end machines.
- Limited communication: In-game communication options are somewhat limited, making it difficult to coordinate with teammates, especially for new players.

Team Fortress 2 is one of my favorite games and hat simulators of all time. It's not really much of a secret, given how many hours I've gotten in it plus the fact I've been playing it for over 10 years (although it was a while before I had a computer that could run it very well). It is more than just a game; it is a whole experience.

The gameplay is very addictive. The gunplay and counters feel just right, and no two classes play the same (which can't be said for some modern hero shooters). Team Fortress 2 showed that you only needed 9 classes maximum, instead of 20 or so. There are crates and microtransactions sure, but they aren't exactly forced upon you; you can simply get free item drops by just playing the game on servers (at least if they are secure VAC-enabled ones). A lot of the maps are very memorable; 2Fort, Dustbowl, Badwater etc. and a dozen of community created maps that would be too much to list here. Even with (non-cheating) singleplayer bots, the game is still very fun.

Personality and style wise, TF2 had the best a shooter game could ever have. The classes are all fun to witness, and even 17 years later they still feel irreplaceable, with perfect voice acting and beyond memorable and hilarious dialog. It's not like some other games where they are just generic, too. Each class was designed with shapes and silhouettes in mind, creating easily identifiable looks (i.e. if someone is outlined behind a wall, you could tell which class it is even from afar). The art-style of the game, inspired by J.C. Leyendecker, really made it timeless, and it still looks good to this day; an incredible feat for a game from 2007, a time when most games went for a muddy realistic look (a large portion of which haven't aged well visually). TF2 went for a heavily researched mixture of being cartoony and grounded, and it worked very, VERY well. It's not like some modern cartoony shooters that don't have reason behind the style, because this one does. There is also a story that is not forced upon you, being told through item descriptions, map objects, comics and shorts. It is wacky and adds a lot more to the game's world.

Now sure, the game has had its rough times. The Meet Your Match update was an attempt at making TF2 appeal to the e-sports scene, when really it was a game that you could pick up and just... play (hence why Quickplay was a thing). There was (currently remedied) also the botting crisis that lead to all sorts of different things (drama, campaigns, review bombings etc.). None of these affect my opinion on the game itself, however. You don't HAVE to play on Casual and Competitive; you can make your own server or join community ones. I only have minor criticisms with some weapon balancing decisions and bugs, but they aren't enough to lower my thoughts on the game. I do also wish that the classes had more unique lines for interacting with each other, rather than them being stuck to domination lines (think Left 4 Dead 2 or even Overwatch, where characters would refer to each other by name and talk if nearby).

I feel this review was long, long overdue (10 years overdue, even). I never really made serious reviews until now, but I figured I'd finally do so. Team Fortress 2 is not only one of the most important shooters, but also one of the most important games alone to me. It's a game that will never die to me, because even if the official servers shut off, you can still host your own and get others to join or play with singleplayer bots. Even playing with stock weapons is still fun. I'll probably still be playing in a decade or more from now. It just never gets old, even 17 years later.

[h3][b][u]Team Fortress 2[/u][/b][/h3] is a team-based first-person shooter developed by Valve Corporation. Released in 2007, it has become a cult classic and remains one of the most popular PC games of all time. Here's a breakdown of what makes TF2 so special:

[b][u]Unique Classes:[/u][/b] TF2 features nine distinct classes, each with its own strengths, weaknesses, and playstyle. The classes are divided into three categories: Offense (Scout, Soldier, Pyro), Defence (Demo-man, Heavy, Engineer), and Support (Medic, Sniper, Spy). Each class has a set of unique abilities, which encourages players to work together as a team and use their skills to overcome opponents.

[b][u]Game Play:[/u][/b] The game play in TF2 is incredibly polished, with tight controls and responsive movement. Players can choose from various game modes, including Capture the Flag, Control Point, and Payload. The objective-based game play and diverse classes ensure that no two matches are ever the same.

[b][u]Visuals and Soundtrack:[/u][/b] TF2's cartoon-ish, stylised visuals have become iconic in the world of gaming. The game's art style, inspired by the works of J.J. Sedelmaier and Chuck Jones, has aged surprisingly well, and the character designs are instantly recognisable. The soundtrack, composed by Mike Morasky and John Patrick Lowrie, is equally impressive, with catchy and humorous theme songs for each class.

[b][u]Community:[/u][/b] The TF2 community is dedicated and passionate, with a strong focus on competitive play and teamwork. While the community can be toxic at times, Valve has implemented various measures to reduce harassment and promote positive behaviour. The game's popularity has also led to the creation of numerous community-made maps, game modes, and cosmetics.

[b][u]Influence:[/u][/b] TF2's influence can be seen in many modern shooters, including Overwatch, Rainbow Six Siege, and Team Fortress's own spiritual successor, Overwatch's Payload mode. The game's innovative game play mechanics, such as the " ubercharge" system and the emphasis on teamwork, have become staples of the genre.

[b][u]Price:[/u][/b] The best part? Team Fortress 2 is completely free to play, with no upfront cost or subscription fees. Players can purchase in-game items and cosmetics, but the core game play experience is entirely free.

[i]Overall, Team Fortress 2 is a game that has stood the test of time, and its unique blend of game play, humour, and style continues to captivate audiences to this day. If you haven't already, do yourself a favour and give it a try – you won't regret it.[/i]

I'm not gonna blurb the whole history, but basically 7 years ago they removed a bunch of skill ceilings, ruining lots of guns and playstyles making previous sidegrades straight up or downgrades. Pyro got a bunch of nonsense which they've helped a little with (flame hitbox was mad broken). Then the updates stopped, and 4 years later or even sooner it was a bot infested hellscape you couldn't hope to play on official servers. They've done ban waves now so in that aspect it's playable again. Matchmaking hasn't been touched since release though so hope you don't mind putting 200hrs in to get the basics and researching playstyles/mechanics. 
   Even with all that there's lots to enjoy here. A shooter where firefights are more than a milisecond, unique playstyles, gamemodes, and communites. It's a game where you experience is what you make of it, like movement shooters? Play an explosives, scout, hell wrangler engie. More of a point and click? Sniper and spy will have you covered. Want a hero shooter less based in moba mechanics? Here you are. All the weapons are free, and for many there's even money to be made (hense bot crisis). If you're going to give it a shot, do your homework first and you'll have a wayy better time. I still probably consider this my favorite game, it's just gotten too disheartening playing in this state. This game introduced me to pc games and I'll always love it deeply, but please don't spend money on it. I need to see valve give more than half a shot to put my heart into it again.

This game has an awesome lore, jokes, characters and one of most creative and strong communities I've ever seen. Yes, it may be hard for newcomers to understand some tactics and features, but thanks for the guides from community, once again. The voice actors of characters are awesome, not gonna lie, I love all of them and their communication with the TF2 community. 
I also would like to say that this game was following me since years of my childhood, and probably will do that for the rest of my life. Honestky I would like to share with people why Misha is my favorite character. He reminds me of myself, and it's easy to me to associate him with myself as well, since I also was born in Siberia. Man, I remember how 2 years ago I recreated sandvich from the official blueprint and still have a photo of it. It was awesome. If you want to try it, you should, but keep in mind that since bot crisis started f2p players will have their chat abilities disabled. Check for premium DLC and if you don't have it, buy a backpack expender at MANNCO store, it will be very helpful for your very start. Good luck!

Compared to other FPS games TF2 offers so much player expression and freedom. Want to carry a game singlehandedly? You can do it and then some. Want to play with a weird strategy or use an off-meta weapon? No one is stopping you. Perhaps you want to master a niche mechanic? There are so many things to explore. I'm sorry to admit I lack the articulation skills to clearly describe just how good it feels.

Is it perfect? No. It has a lot of issues which have just compounded over the years. Not to mention its not an easy game for a new player, but if you put in the effort to improve, you'll have some of the most gratifying and rewarding gameplay you can have online.

[b] Rating: 9/10 [/b]

[i] Team Fortress 2 [/i] is an absolute classic that continues to deliver a unique and endlessly entertaining multiplayer experience. Even after all these years, it remains a standout in the genre, thanks to its distinct style, balanced gameplay, and vibrant community.

The first thing that strikes you about [i] TF2 [/i] is its iconic art style. The cartoonish, exaggerated characters and environments give the game a timeless quality that sets it apart from other shooters. Each of the nine classes is meticulously designed with its own strengths, weaknesses, and playstyles, allowing for a level of strategic depth and team synergy that few games can match.

Gameplay is fast-paced, chaotic, and, most importantly, fun. Whether you’re pushing the payload as a Heavy, setting up sentries as an Engineer, or sneaking behind enemy lines as a Spy, every match feels fresh and dynamic. The game modes are varied and cater to different playstyles, ensuring that there’s always something new to try.

One of [i] TF2’s [/i] greatest strengths is its community. The game has fostered a passionate player base that keeps the experience alive with custom maps, community-designed items, and seasonal in-game events. The humor and personality infused into every aspect of the game make it a joy to play, even when you’re on the losing side.

While [i] TF2 [/i] has seen its share of ups and downs over the years, it’s still a must-play for anyone who enjoys team-based shooters. The occasional matchmaking hiccups and older mechanics are small drawbacks compared to the overall experience.

In short, [i] Team Fortress 2 [/i] is a gem that has aged like fine wine. It’s a game that rewards both skill and teamwork, offering hours upon hours of enjoyment. If you haven’t given it a try yet, now is the perfect time to jump in and see why it’s still one of the best multiplayer games out there.

If you have friends to play with, this game can provide some of the best gaming moments of your life. Each character has a high skill ceiling, but the game can also be enjoyed casually without any issues. Final verdict: Cognitive hazard 10/10

One of the greatest multiplayer experiences of the modern age, Team Fortress 2 has withstood the test of time and then some. This game was one of the most unique and interesting things to come out of gaming, and influenced the world it was made for in ways you can see the after effects of to this day. Team Fortress 2 not only is still alive, but as you'll see from many other reviewers, it's alive and well, despite recent events and controversies. The most recent development, the botting crisis, has been all but resolved now. Where games were unplayable half of the time just months ago, the most recent updates to the game, while still not adding new content, breathed new life into the game in another way. The support it's getting is what it's needed for years. I only hope that it continues, as this is one of my all time favorites.

Team Fortress 2 was released as part of The Orange Box bundle in October 10, 2007. Later on April 9, 2008 it got released as a standalone game. That's around 6141 days ago. People still plays this game and enjoy it, creating content for it, like Cosmetics, Maps, Gamemodes, Charity events and Tournaments. Why?

Because it's a hat game. Hats everywhere. And Fishes. And Frying pans, and hams, and craziness. 
You probably never played a First Person Shooter before or you are a God, but one thing I am sure, you can still learn and have fun here. This is the proof that even after so many years, this game is timeless. I am proud of being a part of this community. 

If you are still doubting about playing it, all I can say is you won't regret it... I hope. Have fun out there!

Title: Timeless Classic - A True Gem in the Gaming World

Review:
I've been playing Team Fortress 2 since its launch, and I can confidently say that no other game has captured my heart quite like this one. From the very beginning, TF2 has stood out with its unique blend of team-based strategy, quirky humor, and fast-paced action. The character classes are perfectly balanced, offering a wide range of playstyles that cater to every type of gamer.

The community is one of the most loyal and passionate I've ever encountered. Whether you're a seasoned veteran or a newcomer, you'll always find a friendly face and a helping hand. 

Team Fortress 2 isn't just a game; it's an experience. Its vibrant art style, iconic characters, and memorable moments have left an indelible mark on the gaming world. If you're looking for a game that offers endless fun, creativity, and a sense of belonging, look no further. TF2 is, and always will be, a timeless masterpiece. Highly recommended!

I played Counter-Strike since 2006, on and off every iteration. Dota since 2009, yes, the WC3 map. League briefly, 2014. War thunder, pretty consistently from 2016. Closest to TF2 was probably Planetside 2, on and off from 2013/2014. Not a single one of those games showed such disdain and neglect towards fresh/worse players. 

NO matchmaking whatsoever. Yes, this guy have 140k kills on this weapon and double the points of their team second place. Yes, thats a 2-man stack with a pocket medic and theyll barell through the map. There is no counterplay, at least not one that i can come up with, with my 25 hours in-game, against their 7000. In a game with high skill ceiling you get yourself into casual pub, to learn the basics. Instead you get THAT. And thats 2 out of 3 games, literally. 
This game also have progression in terms of unlocks. Which just dont happen. Wow, i got 6 new weapons. Out of what, 139? IN 40 HOURS????? How much time am i supposed to waste in those pubs, getting r4ped by another spy/sniper main? Subclasses are cool, except when you cant use them. 
Complete lack of understandable comeback/counterplay mechanics. Like i said, i have NO idea what are you even supposed to do against dustbowl last map defense sticky spam. Or pocketed phlog rush. Or just good ol' banner soldier with 5k hours and endless crits. So many games are just spawn room camps, where you learn nothing, get frustrated and tired. 

And worst of it all, all of this is happening in a supposedly relaxed steam casual pub match. Compare that to Counter Strike, and youll get radically different picture. I tried a LOT of f2p somewhat casual games, and not a single one was this RUTHLESS to a newbie. I have good reflexes and can flick my engie shotgun pretty good, but i still dont understand anything. And the more i play the less i want to learn. 

Wholesome Team Fortress 2 community, filled with memes and whimsy? LIE. Youre getting frontstabbed by a spy main 5 times in a row, and hes gonna put that in tiktok compilation too.

It's a timeless classic, what can I say. Although I should bring up some criticism; the game did hit its peak back around 2009-2012; nowadays it's a spaghetti code nightmare mess of a code, the game is unbalanced far more than it used to be, all the great weapons have been nerfed (demoknight the most) and the artstyle has been all but ruined due to all the cosmetics and certain maps added over the years that clash with the artistic expression of the 1960's of which this game portrays.

Still however, it's extremely addictive and fun to play. I've been playing it since 2007 on the Xbox 360 (way more hours than the amount recorded on this account, and I have had multiple accounts on steam throughout the years). Hell, it was a few years ago, I bought Xbox Live just so I could play the 360 version again and enjoy plain vanilla TF2 without any updates at all. 

Overall, I still love this game in my heart, and highly recommend people play it. It's been long overdue I put a review for this game, but I want to get it off my shoulders.

I personally love TF2. It's a great game to play with friends and can be quite hilarious at times. My only issue is the bot problem. While every once in a while Valve will do something to get rid of the bots, it's inconsistent at best from what I've seen. Other than that, I say TF2 is a must play game and I do recommend you play it. Especially while the bots are still mostly gone.

With over 3500 hours in the game, I have many fond memories of the game.  Thankfully the bot problem seems largely resolved for now.  There for a while there was no amount of rose tinted glasses that could hide the size and scope of the bot problem in casual for the last few years.  Hopefully the update that removed the bots works for some time to come, but we can not forget lest history repeat itself.

Bot problem solved for now, there are some issues with matchmaking that could be addressed, most of which I can live with those for now.  Some of these are the reason I tend to use community servers over matchmaking (if only it weren't so buried and hidden to new players).  Here's to hoping the matchmaking experience can be also improved.  It doesn't need to be a full return to quick play, but it would be nice to not be locked exclusively to your level.  I miss days where a server full of Hoovies or similar could spontaneously happen.  But if this doesn't happen, at least the bot problem is resolved for now.

If Valve can't be trusted to run their games, what about their in-game economies? The lack of care that is shown to this game proves the instability of the markets in which are brought forth by the game itself. If there is not a game to play, but items to be traded, those items have zero value or even hypothetical value. If the market economy dies in this game, who is to say it won't spread to games such as CS2, which has their own economy that functions almost identically to this game. If TF2's economy falters or shows weakness, (which it most certainly is) it is not a stretch to predict this pattern extending to other games due to the definitive proof of error in the speculative value of in-game items. If TF2 does not provide enough money to justify action against the woes of this game, the stability of community markets do. Who is going to willingly invest in a system or game when its counterparts are so effortlessly destroyed? #fixtf2

Leaving this negative review truly breaks my heart, because I've played this game on and off obsessively since I was 14. Months ago, I told myself I would write a positive, heart-gushing review once I hit 2k hours, but it looks like the odds of me reaching that are getting lower and lower. With the FixTF2 movement seemingly failing, I am just about ready to give up hope here. 

This game has aged fantastically and is somehow able to hold up just as well as modern FPS releases, arguably better than most if I'm being honest. It's been a talked-to-death topic already that I won't drag out here, but the short version is this is a fantastic shooter with the perfect amount of mobility mechanics to feel unique and special with a deceptively massive skill ceiling. The main gamemodes all feel different and are all a blast (if you think of CTF as unlimited deathmatch lol). The artstyle is timeless! This game understands that burst damage is the most fun part of any shooter!

I wish I could go on, but anyone reading knows why this is a negative review. Valve's inaction on the bot issue is unacceptable on its own, but the absolute radio silence for YEARS (one damage control tweet that amounted to nothing doesn't count) about the ordeal and about TF2's future in general is downright pathetic for any developer, let alone Valve to be trying to pull. This is an unprecedented level of game neglect unheard of in the industry for an issue that is stopping the game from being playable right now. The only way me, or you, or anyone else in the world can play this game right now is by finding a community server likely owned by penny pinchers that want to throw ads in your face or is otherwise horribly managed. The few well-maintained servers out there are played by people at a skill level that is frankly well beyond the reach of anyone that hasn't already dumped a good couple hundred hours into honing their skill. I've never been a serious player, but even still, with 1,8k hours I can just barely keep up in an Uncletopia server. This problem isn't anyone's fault but Valve's, really. The massive range of low-average skill levels has no place anymore now that Valve servers are mostly unplayable, which is just really tragic to see. I still have fun in Uncletopia / other "sweaty-semi-casual" servers, but essentially anyone close to or below that certain skill level is going to have a tough time in these servers and likely be dogged on for dragging the team down. Meanwhile, if you want to play a Valve server where the skill disparity is a lot less intense, have fun spending 10 minutes or so queuing up for a good 2fort server that isn't infested with bots and playing endless deathmatch, which is admittedly fun but only contains a fraction of the gameplay depth TF2 has to offer, with much less emphasis on the "team" part that really makes the other gamemodes click.

I could rant more, but I feel like I've gotten enough of the point across. If Valve proves me and the rest of the community wrong and shows they can care enough to make some serious fixes, I'll dump these last hours and write that sappy review about how much I love this game.
If not, this might be where it ends for me and this game. Those years before the bot crisis really kicked off were some of the most fun I've ever had.
It's such a shame.

Valve has always done this thing where they don't say a word about anything because it's easier than communicating with your playerbase and then having that playerbase hold you to your word or expect you to do something. Combine that with their casual approach of only having people work on something if they want to, and you get the current state of TF2.

Technically they COULD be doing something, there could be a whole team working on it and trying to figure out how to fix the game, but in reality that's nothing more than wishful thinking. We only know that there's like 1 guy doing barebones maintenance on this game, and bless that person honestly.

However, it just doesn't make any sense. You can ignore any sort of emotional appeal to TF2's legacy, community, importance for the industry or Valve, anything subjective and sentimental? You can wipe that out and it still wouldn't make sense because even if you ignore that, it's still a massive game that makes Valve a truckload of money. 

You'd think it would be in their interest to ensure that the game is in a healthy and appealing state. Not just to avoid bleeding players or attracting new ones (which obviously feeds into trading and their income), but for their own image. You think people would be paying clown prices for a garrish hat with even more hideous special effects if TF2 had 1k players? Obviously not. The same way, investing into a game that might just get abandoned and overrun by cheaters doesn't seem too appealing.

I despise the skin market that Valve created, so it's annoying to make arguments based on it, but it certainly seems like Valve would care more about money than anything else. It seems clear that there's no artistic drive to support something you've created, and there's clearly no sense of responsibility to at least maintain it in a proper state for the sake of hundreds of thousands of people who love TF2.

TF2 is a game with deep and satisfying gameplay, fun characters, and a semi-relaxed atmosphere which is hard to get from PvP shooters these days.
It has its problems. It's full of them, in fact. But despite all of its flaws, TF2 is an inherently fun experience. I grew up with it and I am still playing it all these years later, enjoying the game together with both old and new friends.
Download the game, tweak the default settings so your field of view isn't miserably low, and play whatever character you like. They're all cool in their own ways. Learning can be a bit rough, but in a casual environment victories and losses don't matter much. Focus on doing what feels fun and get better at the game one step at a time.

Team Fortress 2: A Timeless Classic with a Bot Battle
Introduction
Team Fortress 2 (TF2), despite its age, remains a beacon of multiplayer excellence. Developed by Valve and released in 2007, it has stood the test of time. Let’s delve into this iconic game that blends humor, strategy, and chaos.

Visuals and Atmosphere
Time-Tested Aesthetics: While the graphics may not dazzle modern eyes, the art direction is timeless. The quirky characters, vibrant maps, and exaggerated weaponry create a world that’s both absurd and endearing.
Environmental Details: Each map tells a story. From the dusty Badlands to the futuristic 2Fort, every corner is filled with personality. The graffiti, posters, and hidden nooks add depth.
Gameplay and Mechanics
Class-Based Chaos: TF2’s nine distinct classes offer diverse playstyles. Whether you’re a nimble Scout, a cunning Spy, or a heavy-hitting Heavy, there’s a role for everyone.
Weapon Variety: The arsenal is a playground. Rocket launchers, flamethrowers, and sappers—each weapon feels purposeful. And let’s not forget the iconic Medic’s ÜberCharge.
Soundtrack and Sound Design
Earworm Tunes: The quirky soundtrack, including the iconic “More Gun,” sets the tone. The sound effects—critical hits, teleporters, and headshots—are etched in our gaming memories.
Voice Lines: The character voice lines are legendary. “Sentry ahead!” and “Spy sapping my sentry!” are part of gaming folklore.
Bot Battle and Community Outcry
The Bot Problem: TF2’s recent bot infestation has frustrated players. Bots flood servers, disrupting matches and spamming chat. Valve’s response has been slow, leading to community outcry.
Player Protests: Content creators like SquimJim have rallied players to demand action. The flood of messages to media outlets and Valve aims to force change.
Conclusion
Team Fortress 2 is more than a game; it’s a cultural touchstone. Despite the bot woes, its charm endures. Play it for the nostalgia, the camaraderie, and the joy of yelling “MEDIC!” in a firefight.

Rating: 8.5/10
